user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of close_connection:
```c
static void
close_connection (struct MHD_Connection *pos)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = pos->daemon;

#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (daemon->tid) );
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon))
  {
    MHD_connection_mark_closed_ (pos);
    return;   /* must let thread to do the rest */
  }
  MHD_connection_close_ (pos,
                         MHD_REQUEST_TERMINATED_DAEMON_SHUTDOWN);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
  mhd_assert (! pos->suspended);
  mhd_assert (! pos->resuming);
  if (pos->connection_timeout_ms == daemon->connection_timeout_ms)
    XDLL_remove (daemon->normal_timeout_head,
                 daemon->normal_timeout_tail,
                 pos);
  else
    XDLL_remove (daemon->manual_timeout_head,
                 daemon->manual_timeout_tail,
                 pos);
  DLL_remove (daemon->connections_head,
              daemon->connections_tail,
              pos);
  DLL_insert (daemon->cleanup_head,
              daemon->cleanup_tail,
              pos);
  daemon->data_already_pending = true;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The early return inside the if (MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_(daemon)) block makes the remainder of the function unreachable whenever that condition is true; both the if-block (with the return) and the subsequent code path must be examined to ensure no permanently unreachable code exists in any project configuration. Other fragments were not selected because they are either conditional on compilation macros (#ifdef / #if defined) and therefore not inherently unreachable, or are simple assertions and list-manipulation calls that are executed when the thread-per-connection condition is false. Specifically: the top #ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS block contains only assertions compiled conditionally and does not by itself create unreachable code; the mutex lock/unlock calls are guarded by the same compilation macros and are paired (lock present before unlock when those macros are defined); the mhd_assert calls and the XDLL/DLL insert/remove lines are part of the normal execution path when thread-per-connection is not in effect. These other fragments should not be investigated for Rule 2.1 since they are not unconditionally unreachable within the source as presented.
